3) Relevant principles/laws and why they apply (math tools, physics-style reasoning)

Even though this is calculus, the laws are the same ones used in physics modeling (e.g., resonance curves, transfer functions):

  1. Domain & singularities (like poles in physics)

  2. Asymptotic behavior (like far-field approximations)

  3. Derivatives for extrema (like equilibrium points)

PART 3 Full Solution

A) Physical intuition (why the graph looks the way it does)

This function is a rational response curve. In physics terms:

  • The denominator x21x^2-1x21 hits zero at x=1x=\pm1x=1 the response blows up vertical asymptotes (like resonant poles).

  • For large x|x|x, the highest powers dominate: roughly x3x2=x\frac{x^3}{x^2}=xx2x3=x the curve follows a slanted line yxy\approx xyx far away.

  • Peaks/valleys happen where the slope yy'y changes sign (like stable/unstable equilibrium changes).

B) Detailed math derivation (step-by-step)

1) Domain and discontinuities

y=x3x21y=\frac{x^3}{x^2-1}y=x21x3

The denominator cannot be zero:

x210x21x1.x^2-1\neq 0 \quad \Longrightarrow\quad x^2\neq 1 \quad \Longrightarrow\quad x\neq \pm 1.x21=0x2=1x=1.

So the function is discontinuous at:

x=1,x=1.x=-1,\; x=1.x=1,x=1.

Do they cancel (removable)?
Numerator x3x^3x3 has factor xx2x\cdot x^2xx2, denominator is (x1)(x+1)(x-1)(x+1)(x1)(x+1). No cancellation occurs. Therefore these are infinite discontinuities vertical asymptotes.

Discontinuities: x=1x=\pm 1x=1, type: infinite (vertical asymptotes).

2) Asymptotes

(i) Vertical asymptotes

Since x=1x=\pm1x=1 makes denominator 000 with no cancellation:

x=1 and x=1 are vertical asymptotes.\boxed{x=1 \text{ and } x=-1 \text{ are vertical asymptotes.}}x=1 and x=1 are vertical asymptotes.

(ii) Slant (oblique) asymptote

Because the degree of the numerator (3) is one more than the denominator (2), we expect a slant asymptote.

Do polynomial division:

x3x21.\frac{x^3}{x^2-1}.x21x3.

We note:

x3=x(x21)+x.x^3 = x(x^2-1) + x.x3=x(x21)+x.

So:

x3x21=x+xx21.\frac{x^3}{x^2-1} = x + \frac{x}{x^2-1}.x21x3=x+x21x.

As xx\to\pm\inftyx, the remainder term goes to 0:

xx21xx2=1x0.\frac{x}{x^2-1}\sim \frac{x}{x^2}=\frac{1}{x}\to 0.x21xx2x=x10.

So the slant asymptote is:

y=x.\boxed{y=x.}y=x.

3) Behavior near the vertical asymptotes (one-sided limits)

Near x=1x=1x=1

  • If x1x\to 1^-x1, then x21<0x^2-1<0x21<0 (slightly negative) and x3>0x^3>0x3>0.

    x3x21+=.\frac{x^3}{x^2-1}\to \frac{+}{-}=-\infty.x21x3+=.

  • If x1+x\to 1^+x1+, then x21>0x^2-1>0x21>0 and x3>0x^3>0x3>0.

    x3x21++=+.\frac{x^3}{x^2-1}\to \frac{+}{+}=+\infty.x21x3++=+.
limx1y=,limx1+y=+.\boxed{\lim_{x\to 1^-}y=-\infty,\qquad \lim_{x\to 1^+}y=+\infty.}x1limy=,x1+limy=+.

Near x=1x=-1x=1

  • If x(1)x\to (-1)^-x(1) (e.g., 1.1-1.11.1): x21>0x^2-1>0x21>0, but x3<0x^3<0x3<0.

    y+=.y\to \frac{-}{+}=-\infty.y+=.

  • If x(1)+x\to (-1)^+x(1)+ (e.g., 0.9-0.90.9): x21<0x^2-1<0x21<0, and x3<0x^3<0x3<0.

    y=+.y\to \frac{-}{-}=+\infty.y=+.
limx(1)y=,limx(1)+y=+.\boxed{\lim_{x\to (-1)^-}y=-\infty,\qquad \lim_{x\to (-1)^+}y=+\infty.}x(1)limy=,x(1)+limy=+.

4) Intercepts and symmetry (helps the sketch)

Intercept

y(0)=01=0(0,0) is an intercept.y(0)=\frac{0}{-1}=0 \quad\Rightarrow\quad (0,0) \text{ is an intercept.}y(0)=10=0(0,0) is an intercept.

Odd symmetry

Check y(x)y(-x)y(x):

y(x)=(x)3(x)21=x3x21=y(x).y(-x)=\frac{(-x)^3}{(-x)^2-1}=\frac{-x^3}{x^2-1}=-y(x).y(x)=(x)21(x)3=x21x3=y(x).

So the function is odd, meaning the graph has origin symmetry.

This is a big sketch shortcut: left side is a 180 rotation of the right side.

5) Local maxima and minima (critical points)

Step 1: Differentiate

Use the simplified form:

y=x+xx21.y=x+\frac{x}{x^2-1}.y=x+x21x.

Differentiate:

ddx[x]=1.\frac{d}{dx}[x]=1.dxd[x]=1.

For xx21\displaystyle \frac{x}{x^2-1}x21x, use quotient rule:

(xx21)=(x21)1x(2x)(x21)2=x212x2(x21)2=x21(x21)2=x2+1(x21)2.\left(\frac{x}{x^2-1}\right)'=\frac{(x^2-1)\cdot 1 - x\cdot (2x)}{(x^2-1)^2} =\frac{x^2-1-2x^2}{(x^2-1)^2} =\frac{-x^2-1}{(x^2-1)^2} =-\frac{x^2+1}{(x^2-1)^2}.(x21x)=(x21)2(x21)1x(2x)=(x21)2x212x2=(x21)2x21=(x21)2x2+1.

So:

y=1x2+1(x21)2.y' = 1 - \frac{x^2+1}{(x^2-1)^2}.y=1(x21)2x2+1.

Put over a common denominator:

y=(x21)2(x2+1)(x21)2.y'=\frac{(x^2-1)^2-(x^2+1)}{(x^2-1)^2}.y=(x21)2(x21)2(x2+1).

Expand (x21)2=x42x2+1(x^2-1)^2=x^4-2x^2+1(x21)2=x42x2+1:

(x42x2+1)(x2+1)=x43x2.(x^4-2x^2+1)-(x^2+1)=x^4-3x^2.(x42x2+1)(x2+1)=x43x2.

Thus:

y=x43x2(x21)2=x2(x23)(x21)2.y'=\frac{x^4-3x^2}{(x^2-1)^2} =\frac{x^2(x^2-3)}{(x^2-1)^2}.y=(x21)2x43x2=(x21)2x2(x23).

Step 2: Solve y=0y'=0y=0 (in the domain)

A fraction is zero when its numerator is zero:

x2(x23)=0x^2(x^2-3)=0x2(x23)=0

So:

x2=0x=0,x23=0x=3.x^2=0 \Rightarrow x=0,\qquad x^2-3=0\Rightarrow x=\pm\sqrt{3}.x2=0x=0,x23=0x=3.

All are allowed (none equals 1\pm11).

Step 3: Classify using sign changes of yy'y

Note:

  • Denominator (x21)2>0(x^2-1)^2>0(x21)2>0 wherever defined, so it never changes sign.

  • x20x^2\ge 0x20, and is zero only at x=0x=0x=0.

  • So the sign is controlled by (x23)(x^2-3)(x23).

  • If x>3|x|>\sqrt{3}x>3, then x23>0x^2-3>0x23>0 y>0y'>0y>0 (increasing).

  • If x<3|x|<\sqrt{3}x<3, then x23<0x^2-3<0x23<0 y<0y'<0y<0 (decreasing), except at the single point x=0x=0x=0 where y=0y'=0y=0 but the sign does not flip.

Now check around each critical point:

  • At x=3x=-\sqrt{3}x=3: yy'y goes +++ (for x<3x<- \sqrt{3}x<3) to - (for 3<x<1-\sqrt{3}<x<-13<x<1).
    Local maximum at x=3x=-\sqrt{3}x=3.

  • At x=3x=\sqrt{3}x=3: yy'y goes - (for 1<x<31<x<\sqrt{3}1<x<3) to +++ (for x>3x>\sqrt{3}x>3).
    Local minimum at x=3x=\sqrt{3}x=3.

  • At x=0x=0x=0: the factor x2x^2x2 makes y=0y'=0y=0 but does not change sign (still decreasing on both sides inside (1,1)(-1,1)(1,1)).
    Not a max/min its a stationary (flat) inflection-type point.

Step 4: Compute the coordinates of extrema

Evaluate yyy at x=3x=\pm\sqrt{3}x=3:

y(3)=(3)3(3)21=(33)31=332.y(\pm\sqrt{3})=\frac{(\pm\sqrt{3})^3}{(\pm\sqrt{3})^2-1} =\frac{\pm(3\sqrt{3})}{3-1} =\pm\frac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}.y(3)=(3)21(3)3=31(33)=233.

So:

Local max at (3,332)\boxed{\text{Local max at }\left(-\sqrt{3},\,-\frac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)}Local max at (3,233) Local min at (3,332)\boxed{\text{Local min at }\left(\sqrt{3},\,\frac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)}Local min at (3,233)

Numerically (for sketching), since 31.73\sqrt{3}\approx 1.7331.73:

3323(1.73)25.1922.60.\frac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}\approx \frac{3(1.73)}{2}\approx \frac{5.19}{2}\approx 2.60.23323(1.73)25.192.60.

6) End behavior as xx\to\pm\inftyx

From:

y=x+xx21,y = x+\frac{x}{x^2-1},y=x+x21x,

and xx210\frac{x}{x^2-1}\to 0x21x0, we get:

Sanity checks (as requested)

Units

  • No physical units here; its dimensionless math.

Limiting cases

  • For large x|x|x: yxy\approx xyx. This matches the slant asymptote.

  • Near x=1x=\pm1x=1: denominator 0\to 00 so y|y|\to\inftyy.

There is a point P=(4,1)P=(4,1)P=(4,1) in the plane. We must find the point (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) on the parabola that is closest (in Euclidean distance) to PPP, and give its coordinates.

PART 3 Full Solution

1) Physical intuition (what closest means geometrically)

The closest point on a smooth curve to a fixed point occurs where the segment from the point to the curve hits the curve along the normal direction (perpendicular to the tangent). Thats the same idea as the shortest path is straight and orthogonal to the constraint surface.

Well implement this via minimizing squared distance.

2) Set up the squared distance function

A general point QQQ on the parabola y=12x2y=\frac12x^2y=21x2 can be written as:

Q(x)=(x,12x2).Q(x)=\left(x,\frac12x^2\right).Q(x)=(x,21x2).

Distance squared from Q(x)Q(x)Q(x) to P(4,1)P(4,1)P(4,1) is:

D2(x)=(x4)2+(12x21)2.D^2(x) = (x-4)^2+\left(\frac12x^2-1\right)^2.D2(x)=(x4)2+(21x21)2.

We minimize D2D^2D2 instead of DDD because D0D\ge 0D0 and squaring is monotonic.

3) Differentiate and find critical points

Differentiate term by term.

Derivative of the first term

ddx(x4)2=2(x4).\frac{d}{dx}(x-4)^2 = 2(x-4).dxd(x4)2=2(x4).

Derivative of the second term (chain rule)

Let

u(x)=12x21.u(x)=\frac12x^2-1.u(x)=21x21.

Then the term is u(x)2u(x)^2u(x)2, so

ddxu2=2uu.\frac{d}{dx}\,u^2 = 2u\cdot u'.dxdu2=2uu.

Compute uu'u:

u(x)=ddx(12x21)=x.u'(x)=\frac{d}{dx}\left(\frac12x^2-1\right)=x.u(x)=dxd(21x21)=x.

So

  • Ratio 1/s\to 1/\text{s}1/s, which matches rad/s since radians are dimensionless.

2) Limiting cases

  • If x=0\dot{x}=0x=0 and y>0\dot{y}>0y>0, angle should increase: formula gives =xyx2+y2>0\dot{\theta}=\frac{x\dot{y}}{x^2+y^2}>0=x2+y2xy>0.

  • If y=0\dot{y}=0y=0 and x>0\dot{x}>0x>0 (moving right), angle should decrease: =yxx2+y2<0\dot{\theta}=\frac{-y\dot{x}}{x^2+y^2}<0=x2+y2yx<0.

3) Physical interpretation

At this instant, the segment is getting steeper because yyy increases while xxx decreases, so \theta increases rapidly: 3 rad/s3\ \text{rad/s}3 rad/s (about 172/s172^\circ/\text{s}172/s), consistent with the strong horizontal speed x=20|\dot{x}|=20x=20 m/s.
